chapter.summary: Covers the management of otitis media with effusion (OME) in children, advice for parents, the treatment options available in secondary care, and the management of children with grommets (ventilation tubes) inserted.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From birth to 12 years.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage children with otitis media with effusion (OME)?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Active observation over 6–12 weeks is appropriate for most children, as spontaneous resolution is common.
    • During this period, it is essential to re-evaluate signs and symptoms of the effusion and concerns regarding the child's hearing or language development, and to look for any complications, as this will determine whether it is appropriate to continue with active observation or refer to the child to an ear, nose, and throat (ENT) specialist.
    • Ideally, this should include two hearing tests using pure tone audiometry at least 3 months apart as well as tympanometry.
      • Following the hearing test, the decision to refer to an ENT specialist will depend on the severity of any confirmed hearing loss and suspicion of a delay in the child reaching developmental milestones. For more information, see the section Referral to ENT.
    • If signs and symptoms persist after the period of observation, refer the child to an ENT specialist.
  • Children with Down's syndrome, or cleft palate, who are suspected to have otitis media with effusion (OME) require immediate referral for specialist assessment.
  • Note: The following treatments are not recommended for treating OME, as there is no evidence to support their use:
    • Antibiotics.
    • Antihistamines.
    • Mucolytics.
    • Decongestants.
    • Corticosteroids.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health clinical guideline Surgical management of otitis media with effusion in children [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2008] and a British Medical Journal (BMJ) article Otitis media with effusion (“glue ear”) [Farboud, 2011].

subChapters.fullItemName: Non-surgical treatment options in secondary care
subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the non-surgical treatment options for otitis media with effusion in secondary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Following referral to an ear, nose, and throat (ENT) specialist, non-surgical options for management include:

  • Active observation 
    • A period of 3 months is recommended during which regular follow up should involve a repeated history and examination, audiology, and sometimes speech and language assessment.
  • Hearing aids
    • These may be offered to children with persistent bilateral otitis media with effusion (OME) and hearing loss as an alternative to surgical intervention where surgery is contraindicated or not acceptable.
  • Autoinflation
    • This may be considered during the active observation period for children with OME who are likely to cooperate with the procedure (usually older children).
      • Autoinflation should not be carried out if the child has an upper respiratory infection and should be abandoned if it causes pain.
      • Autoinflation by nasal balloon involves blowing up a balloon via the nostril two to three times a day, thus ventilating the middle ear, equilibrating pressure, and allowing some drainage of fluid. 
      • This procedure is the Valsalva manoeuvre, which in older children can be completed without the balloon. The nostrils are pinched and the mouth is shut whilst air is forcibly exhaled.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health clinical guideline Surgical management of otitis media with effusion in children [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2008] and a National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) briefing Otovent nasal balloon for otitis media with effusion [NICE, 2016].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the surgical options for children with otitis media with effusion?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Myringotomy, and insertion of grommets (ventilation tubes) is the most common surgical option for otitis media with effusion (OME), with or without adenoidectomy.
    • It should be offered as an alternative to hearing aids in children with cleft palate who have OME and persistent hearing loss.
    • Before grommets are offered as an alternative to hearing aids for treating OME in children with Down’s syndrome, the following factors should be considered:
      • Severity of hearing loss.
      • Age of the child.
      • Practicality of grommet insertion.
      • Associated risks.
      • Likelihood of early extrusion of grommets.
  • The procedure improves hearing in the short-term, but has not been shown to improve other aspects of development.
  • Adjuvant adenoidectomy is not recommended in the absence of persistent and/or frequent upper respiratory tract symptoms.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health clinical guideline Surgical management of otitis media with effusion in children [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2008].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage children who have had grommets inserted to treat otitis media with effusion (OME)?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Children who have had grommets (ventilation tubes) inserted should be followed up periodically and their hearing should be re-assessed.
    • Continue follow-up until the grommets have been extruded and the eardrum has healed.
      • Grommets usually stop functioning after an average of 10 months, and a third to half of the children who have grommets will need reinsertion within 5 years.
    • If symptoms of otitis media with effusion (OME) recur, refer the child back to an ear, nose, and throat (ENT) specialist.
  • Be alert to the presence of any complications associated with grommets, including: 
    • Otorrhoea (ear discharge) — the most common complication occuring in 1 in 5 children.
      • Consider a course of topical or oral antibiotics if otorrhoea is problematic, or referring to ENT. 
    • Infection — for more information, see the CKS topic on Otitis media - acute.
    • Tympanosclerosis — affects about 1 in 3 children younger than 5 years of age.
    • Perforation of the tympanic membrane.
    • Fibrosis.
    • Cholesteatoma.
    • Bleeding.
  • Advise the parent of the following:
    • Grommets usually cause few problems and work their way out of the ear in time.
    • Normal school activities should be encouraged.
    • Normal holiday activities (including flying by aeroplane) should also not cause problems.
    • Normal swimming should not be discouraged, as it does not increase the risk of infection.
      • Swimming caps or ear plugs do not give any additional protection against infection. However, it is probably prudent to advise against diving, particularly at significant depth.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on a Cochrane systematic review [Browning et al, 2010], randomized controlled trials (RCTs) [MRC Multicentre Otitis Media Study Group, 2003], an ENT UK patient leaflet About grommets in children  a British Medical Journal (BMJ) Clinical Evidence article Otitis media with effusion in children [Williamson, 2015], and the expert opinion of CKS reviewers.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information and advice can I give to parents of children with otitis media with effusion (OME)?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Reassure parents that:
    • Otitis media with effusion (OME) has a very good prognosis. 
    • Active observation for several months rarely results in long-term complications.
    • There is no proven benefit from treatment with any medication, or any complementary, or alternative therapies.
  • Advise parents that parental smoking increases the risk of OME.
  • Give parents the following advice to reduce the impact of hearing loss on the child's education at home and school:
    • When speaking to the child, face them, slow the rate of speech, raise the level, and speak clearly.
    • Turn off competing auditory stimuli, such as music or television.
    • Daily reading helps language development. Books with explanatory pictures are useful.
    • Discuss seating arrangements with the school, ideally placing the child near the teacher.
  • Give parents appropriate advice about grommets such as:
    • Grommets usually cause few problems and work their way out of the ear in time.
    • Normal school activities should be encouraged.
    • Normal holiday activities (including flying by aeroplane) should also not cause problems.
    • Normal swimming should not be discouraged, as it does not increase the risk of infection.
    • Swimming caps or ear plugs do not give any additional protection against infection. However, it is probably prudent to advise against diving, particularly at significant depth.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The recommendations are largely based on the American Academy of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery (AAO-HNS) clinical guideline Otitis media with effusion [Rosenfeld, 2016], and what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I consider referral to an ear, nose, and throat (ENT) specialist?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Refer to an ear, nose, and throat (ENT) specialist, if:
    • Hearing loss of any level is associated with a significant impact on the child's developmental, social, or educational status.
    • Hearing loss is severe (61 dB or greater) and requires urgent referral within 2 weeks to exclude additional sensorineural deafness.
    • Significant hearing loss persists on two documented occasions (usually following repeat testing after 6–12 weeks).
    • The tympanic membrane is structurally abnormal (or there are other features suggesting an alternative diagnosis).
    • There is a persistent, foul-smelling discharge suggestive of a possible cholesteatoma. Referral should be semi-urgent. For more information please see our CKS topic on Cholesteatoma.
    • The child has Down's syndrome or has a cleft palate.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health clinical guideline Surgical management of otitis media with effusion in children [National Collaborating Centre for Women's and Children's Health, 2008] and the American Academy of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery (AAO-HNS) clinical guideline Otitis media with effusion  [Rosenfeld, 2016].
